awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2023 ACM/IEEE Symposium on Edge Computing (ACM/IEEE SEC)
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposal is to seek travel support for up to 20 students to attend the 2023  ACM/IEEE Symposium on Edge Computing (ACM/IEEE SEC) in Wilmington, DE. This leading technical conference is the primary venue for presenting new research results in the area of "edge computing", a new paradigm in which the resources of a small data center are placed at the edge of the Internet, in close proximity to mobile devices, sensors, and end users, and the emerging Internet of Things(IoT). The conference will consist of technical paper presentations, panels, PhD forums, posters, and demonstrations. It will also feature keynote speeches from leading researchers and practitioners in the field.

Participation in SEC 2023 and similar conferences are valuable and important activities of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers, and exposes students to leading work and practical industry practices in this important area of research. This may have an important impact on career development. The goal of the funds is to support approximately 20 student participants at recognized US institutions of higher education. Funds will be dispersed with preference given to students who would not otherwise be able to attend the conference and students who are not already scheduled to present a paper, paying particular attention to diversity and relevance of the student's research interest.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to support the travels of US-based students to attend the ACM/IEEE Symposium on Edge Computing (SEC), which took place in Wilmington, Delaware, December 6-9, 2023. By supporting student attendance, the grant helped foster knowledge sharing and professional development in edge computing, a critical field within Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE). The event offered an enriching experience through presentations, forums, and networking opportunities with experts in academia and industry.

A total of 25 U.S.-based students were selected from 29 applicants to receive travel support, with each awarded up to $800. An additional three students who were not U.S.-based received conference sponsorship to attend. Notably:

-       Diversity and Inclusion: Of the 25 grant recipients, 4 (16%) are from underrepresented groups in CISE, and 23 (92%) were attending the SEC conference for the first time. This diversity strengthens the field by bringing varied perspectives and fostering inclusivity within CISE.

-       Research Presentation: More than half of the recipients (17 students, or 68%) presented first-authored papers, showcasing their research and engaging in scholarly discussions on the latest advances in edge computing.

In alignment with SEC's commitment to knowledge sharing, this year's grant recipients contributed to conference documentation. 8 students (32%) summarized key insights from the keynote speeches, panels and oral presentations, ensuring that valuable information was accessible to a broader audience. The compiled minutes are now available on the SEC2023 conference website, serving as a resource for attendees and those who could not attend in person.

The travel grant provided crucial support, ensuring that students from varied backgrounds could participate in a prestigious conference, expanding their academic and professional horizons. The grant particularly helped first-time attendees integrate into the professional community, network with peers and mentors, and gain exposure to cutting-edge research, facilitating their future contributions to the field.

This initiative supports NSF's mission by:

-       Promoting Workforce Diversity: The inclusion of female students and individuals from underrepresented groups strengthens the representation of diverse voices in the edge computing community, enhancing innovation and inclusivity.

-       Cultivating Future Leaders: Exposure to current research and professional networks empowers these students to pursue impactful careers, contributing to the broader STEM ecosystem in academia, industry, and beyond.

All funded students actively engaged in conference activities, including the poster and demo sessions, which allowed them to discuss their work and learn from peers. The full list of travel grant recipients includes:

-       Can Cui, Purdue University

-       Yuru Zhang, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

-       Yi Liu, University of California Santa Cruz

-       Stephen Piccolo, Rowan University

-       Yongjie Xue, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

-       Honghao Zheng, Virginia Tech

-       Mihir Bala, Carnegie Mellon University

-       Xiangliang Chen, Carnegie Mellon University

-       Xiaotian Li, New York University

-       Tianyu Bai, University of North Texas

-       Ruixuan Wang, Villanova University

-       Qianlin Liang, University of Massachusetts, Amherst

-       Yunge Li, Oakland University

-       Shaibal Saha, Oakland University

-       Nikolaos Ntokos, University of Texas at Arlington

-       Xuanzhang Liu, Temple University

-       Roja Eswaran, Binghamton University

-       Yongzhou Chen, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign

-       Hongyu Ke, Georgia State University

-       Xiaolong Tu, Georgia State University

-       Salmane Douch, University of Houston

-       Guohuan Feng, Oakland University

-       Alicia Esquivel Morel, University of Missouri - Columbia

-       Kaiqi Zhao, Arizona State University

-       Yitao Chen, Arizona State University


Last Modified: 11/09/2024
Modified by: Lanyu Xu
